case_vignette: A 62-year-old man presents to your office for evaluation of a chronic ulcer on the plantar aspect of his right foot. He has a history of peripheral vascular disease and poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus. He states that he has had this ulcer for years, but that it seems to be growing. On examination of his right foot you note the heaped up edges surrounding the ulcer (Figure A). A wedge biopsy reveals irregular masses of anaplastic epidermal cells proliferating down to the dermis and the pathologist reports "keratin pearls".
question: What is the diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've got a long-lasting sore on the bottom of my right foot that seems to be getting bigger.
How long have you had the sore for, and has it changed in color or consistency?
I've had this sore for years, but I haven't noticed any specific changes in color or consistency.
Do you have any medical conditions, such as diabetes, that could affect healing?
Yes, I have poorly-controlled diabetes and also something called peripheral vascular disease.
Have you suffered from similar sores or wounds on your foot or anywhere else on your body in the past?
No, it's just this one on my foot.
Is the sore painful, or have you lost any sensation around the area?
I haven't really mentioned anything about it being painful or losing sensation around it.
Has the sore continued to deepen or spread over the years, or has it remained relatively the same size?
It seems to be growing.
Has anyone in your family had similar long-lasting sores or issues with healing?
I haven't said anything about my family having similar issues.
Have you tried any treatments so far for the sore?
I haven't mentioned trying any treatments for it.
Are there any signs of infection such as redness, heat, swelling, or discharge from the sore?
I haven't described any signs of infection like that.
Final Diagnosis: Diabetic foot ulcer.
